context_of_use: This use case ensures that the web application delivers multilingual support, fast system responses, and sufficient capacity to handle large numbers of concurrent users so that fans can use the application effectively and IFA administrators can avoid accessibility problems.
stakeholders_and_interests: Fan: Wants to use the application in a native language to understand all provided information clearly.
Fan: Wants to receive fast responses from the system to avoid wasting time waiting.
IFA administrator: Wants the web application to support up to 50,000 concurrent users to avoid accessibility problems.
IFA administrator: Wants application quality characteristics to align with organizational service level expectations.
CIO: Wants improved communication and transparency among stakeholders supported by a performant and accessible application.
description: This use case specifies how the system shall provide multilingual support, fast system responses, and capacity to host up to 50,000 concurrent users, ensuring that fans can effectively interact with the application and IFA administrators can maintain accessibility and service quality.
triggering_event: A fan or IFA administrator initiates interaction with the web application requiring understandable information, prompt responses, or simultaneous access for many users.
preconditions: The IFA web application platform is deployed and operational.
The fan or IFA administrator has network connectivity to access the web application.
At least one default language is configured for the web application.
System performance and capacity settings are configured by the IFA administrator according to organizational policies.
postconditions: The fan has interacted with the web application in a chosen language that is supported by the system.
The fan has received system responses within the defined acceptable response time under normal load conditions.
The IFA web application has supported concurrent access for up to the configured maximum number of users without denying access due to capacity limits under designed operating conditions.
assumptions: It is assumed that the web application provides a finite set of supported languages that can be selected by the fan.

It is assumed that the acceptable system response time is defined by organizational non-functional requirements and service level objectives, even though specific thresholds are not stated in the requirement text.
It is assumed that hosting up to 50,000 concurrent users refers to the maximum number of users simultaneously connected to and using the web application under normal operating conditions.

It is assumed that the IFA administrator is responsible for configuring and maintaining the infrastructure and settings required to achieve the desired capacity and response times, without adding new functional capabilities beyond those described.
It is assumed that application quality characteristics described in this use case are non-functional properties of existing features rather than new user-visible functional features.
requirements_met: The system shall allow a fan to use the application in the fan's native language, provided that the language is supported by the application.
The system shall present all user interface text and content in the language selected by the fan when that language is supported.

The system shall provide fast responses to fan-initiated requests so that the fan does not spend excessive time waiting for pages or actions to complete, in accordance with defined performance thresholds.
The system shall be able to host up to 50,000 concurrent users on the web application under designed operating conditions to avoid accessibility problems.
The system shall maintain acceptable response times, as defined by organizational performance criteria, when up to the configured maximum number of concurrent users are accessing the web application.
The system shall ensure that application access remains available to fans and IFA administrators when the number of concurrent users is at or below the supported capacity limit.
outstanding_issues: The precise list of supported languages and how they are selected by the fan has not been defined.
Quantitative performance targets for 'fast responses' (for example, maximum acceptable response times per request type) are not specified.
The exact operational definition and measurement method for 'up to 50,000 concurrent users' has not been detailed (e.g., session definition, request patterns, peak duration).
Capacity planning responsibilities and the infrastructure environment required to sustain 50,000 concurrent users have not been fully described.
Error handling behavior when the concurrent user limit is reached (e.g., queuing, informative messages) has not been specified.
main_flow: 1. Fan initiates access to the web application → System establishes a session for the fan and loads the default user interface.
2. Fan reviews the displayed language of the user interface → System presents all visible interface elements in the currently configured language.
3. Fan selects a preferred supported language for using the application → System applies the selected language and reloads or updates all relevant interface text and labels accordingly.

4. Fan performs navigation and actions within the web application (such as viewing information pages or accessing features) → System processes each request and returns the requested content or result in the selected language.

5. System handles incoming requests from all active users, including the current fan, while the number of simultaneous users is within the supported capacity → System allocates resources to serve up to the configured maximum number of concurrent sessions, maintaining access to the application.

6. Fan issues one or more additional requests that require server-side processing (such as loading pages, submitting forms, or retrieving data) → System processes each fan request and returns the corresponding response within the configured acceptable response time under normal operating load.

7. Fan continues to interact using the application in the chosen language → System consistently maintains the selected language for all subsequent responses during the session, subject to supported language coverage.

8. System maintains service availability and response performance while concurrent usage increases up to the supported capacity limit → System continues accepting new user sessions and processing requests without denying access due to capacity under designed operating conditions.

9. Fan finishes the interaction or logs out of the application → System terminates or marks the fan session as completed while having provided multilingual, fast-response, and high-capacity service characteristics during the interaction.
alternative_flows: AF-1 (from Step 3): Fan keeps the default language. Condition: The fan decides not to change the language and continues using the application in the default language presented by the system. Flow: The fan does not perform a language change action, proceeds directly to navigation and actions described in Step 4, and the system continues to use the default language for all subsequent responses.

AF-2 (from Step 5): Concurrent users remain below typical load. Condition: The number of concurrent users is significantly below the configured maximum capacity. Flow: The system allocates fewer resources than the defined maximum thresholds but still processes all fan requests; the flow continues with Step 6, and the system may achieve response times faster than the configured maximum acceptable threshold.

AF-3 (from Step 7): Fan changes the preferred supported language during the session. Condition: The fan decides to switch to another supported language while already interacting with the system. Flow: The fan selects a different supported language, the system updates interface text and subsequent responses to the newly selected language, and the flow continues with Step 7 and Step 8 using the new language.
exception_flows: EF-1 (from Step 3): Selected language is not supported by the system. Condition: The fan attempts to select a language that is not configured as supported. Flow: The system rejects the selection, presents an explanatory message indicating that the requested language is unavailable, retains the previously active language, and returns the fan to the state prior to attempting the language change to allow selection of a supported language or continuation with the current language.

EF-2 (from Step 5): Concurrent user load exceeds supported capacity. Condition: The number of concurrent users attempting to access the web application exceeds the supported limit under designed operating conditions. Flow: The system cannot accept additional sessions beyond the supported capacity, prevents the creation of new sessions, and displays an informative message to affected users indicating that the service is temporarily at capacity; existing active sessions, including the current fan session, continue as long as resources permit, and no further progression beyond this point occurs for users whose access was denied.

EF-3 (from Step 6): System fails to respond within acceptable response time. Condition: Due to internal issues or load conditions, the system cannot generate a response for a fan request within the configured acceptable response time. Flow: The system records the performance issue, may time out the pending request, displays an appropriate timeout or error message to the fan, and stops processing the affected request; the fan may attempt the action again by re-initiating the relevant main flow steps.
information_for_steps: 1. Session identifier, client device information, network connection details.
2. Current language code, localized user interface text resources.
3. List of supported language codes, selected language preference, user language settings.
4. Navigation parameters, requested resource identifiers, localized content data.
5. Number of active user sessions, capacity thresholds, resource allocation parameters.
6. Request payload data, processing duration metrics, response payload data, response time measurements.
7. Updated language preference, session-level localization settings, localized response content.
8. Concurrent user count, throughput metrics, performance and availability monitoring data.
9. Session termination flag, session log data, quality-of-service metrics for the completed interaction.
